nodes.bodyText:
I think this is not really right, because we have two possibilities.
One is: you could connect.
The other is: you could connect, but the hostname was empty.
This should change to something like:
 raise "Cannot connect to #{node} to get its hostname. Response code: #{code}" if code.nonzero?
 raise "No hostname for #{node}. Response code: #{code}" if hostname.empty?

And the same for FQDN below.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -84,14 +84,14 @@
   next if node.nil?
 
   hostname, _local, _remote, code = node.test_and_store_results_together('hostname', 'root', 500)
-  raise "Cannot get hostname for node. Response code: #{code}" if code.nonzero? || hostname.empty?
+  raise "Cannot connect to #{node} to get its hostname. Response code: #{code}" if code.nonzero? || hostname.empty?

@@ -84,14 +84,14 @@
   next if node.nil?
 
   hostname, _local, _remote, code = node.test_and_store_results_together('hostname', 'root', 500)
-  raise "Cannot get hostname for node. Response code: #{code}" if code.nonzero? || hostname.empty?
+  raise "Cannot connect to #{node} to get its hostname. Response code: #{code}" if code.nonzero? || hostname.empty?

@@ -84,14 +84,14 @@
   next if node.nil?
 
   hostname, _local, _remote, code = node.test_and_store_results_together('hostname', 'root', 500)
-  raise "Cannot get hostname for node. Response code: #{code}" if code.nonzero? || hostname.empty?
+  raise "Cannot connect to #{node} to get its hostname. Response code: #{code}" if code.nonzero? || hostname.empty?

nodes.bodyText:
Why are not showing the node name again?
I'd add #{node} (or whatever has the node name) to all messages otherwise we never know about what node the error is.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -84,14 +84,16 @@
   next if node.nil?
 
   hostname, _local, _remote, code = node.test_and_store_results_together('hostname', 'root', 500)
-  raise "Cannot get hostname for node. Response code: #{code}" if code.nonzero? || hostname.empty?
+  raise "Cannot connect to get client's hostname. Response code: #{code}" if code.nonzero?

nodes.bodyText: I wasn't exact about the content of node variable before. It is based on FQDN, but it is not simple string, it is instance of Twopence. Simple said it is egg and chicken problem, we cannot get hostname or FQDN before it is initialized :-/ It is probably reason, why it wasn't here before.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -84,14 +84,16 @@
   next if node.nil?
 
   hostname, _local, _remote, code = node.test_and_store_results_together('hostname', 'root', 500)
-  raise "Cannot get hostname for node. Response code: #{code}" if code.nonzero? || hostname.empty?
+  raise "Cannot connect to get client's hostname. Response code: #{code}" if code.nonzero?

nodes.bodyText:
Yep, I fall it to the same case sometime ago, I went even to the C code of Twopence to see what it was there, and I couldn't find a way to show here the name.
I'm wondering if Twopence it's really bringing something extra comparing to an easy Ruby class for the remote nodes, like the one I implemented here:
https://github.com/srbarrios/cucumber-ruby-skeleton/blob/master/features/support/remote_node.rb

nodes.bodyText: @srbarrios I am glad I am not the only one ;-) I listed all available methods for Twopence and it just wasn't there. I also checked C source, but I still thought I had to miss it I expect something like that must be part of basic Twopence functionality.
